1.content:
The burial was the hardest Part. Standing in the rain I didn’t know what to feel. I could feel the cold droplets falling in from the sky as I stood there and looked at the three fresh mounds of dirt. I couldn’t believe they were gone. It was only a week ago we were standing in the midst of the Amazon Rain Forest, hiking and trekking through the trees. I thought that it would be okay, that our family could withstand the conditions. I was wrong, so, so horribly wrong. The next day we flew home, we all had a severe case of pneumonia and some other type of mutant disease. I was the only one resilient to it; the doctor had come in in the middle of the night to tell me that my family had passed on. I didn’t know what to think at the moment. I knew I had to do something; I went and saw them in the middle of the night. The doctor had been right they were dead. The body heat rapidly fading from their now lifeless shells. I had been numb to it all.
I snapped back to reality, the cold rain beating onto my head had ceased as my girlfriend came and put an umbrella over my head. I continued to stare blankly at the three mounds of dirt. She wrapped a blanket around and me and spoke in the sweetest of tones but I didn’t hear her. My mind was on the guilt, the pain that all of this was my idea, even though it wasn’t I couldn’t help but blaming myself, couldn’t help but asking God, why me. She nudged me and my head finally cleared to the point of where I could hear her again.
“John, let’s get you inside and warmed up.” Her soothing voice floated softly into my ears. It was just then that I realized that I had been shaking. i let her lead me to the car that the funeral home had provided. She got me inside and hugged me close as I stared out the window and watched the rain turn to snow. It fell so peacefully as it slowly started to cover the ground. The three mounds of dirt slowly went from dirt brown to white with brown spots. I stared out the window as we drove away and I told myself that I needed to go on with my life, I had to get over this. I felt Melissa’s warm arm over my back and I turned to her, the pain of death was etched deep into her face. “I talked to my parents. They said that I could stay with you at your house for a couple of days, help you sort stuff out. I thought you might like that” she said.
I merely nodded at the idea, showing my appreciation but not having to use words for it. I thought to all of the stuff we had at our house. We were rich, I will put it bluntly. Every year it was a new vacation, a new spot, a new memory, we always brought hundreds of dollars of stuff home with us, and our house was one of the nicest on the block. But that didn’t make us total snobs, my dad’s morale’s had kept us in line. He always preached about us being kind to those who were less fortunate around us and treat those who were our equals with that same kindness. The lawyer had told me that everything in the house including the house itself was mine, the business that had kept us floating and allowed our wealth was being managed by my dad’s main man Ronald Terrepet. I was told his last name was German but he always argued it was something else. The lawyer had also said that I was allowed all of the family inheritance when I was eighteen which would be coming up in about four months. I didn’t flaunt my riches at all, I actually appalled them. I worked a part-time job, against my parents’ wishes of course, but I only worked weekends. I bought average clothes and went to an average school but always got good grades.My friends were average people, never asking for money but treating with a fairness that I could only find through good friends. I lived a normal teenage life up until the beginning of the week, when that virus killed my family. I finally turned to my girlfriend and said “that will be great.”
She stared at me and had a puzzled look on her face; I told her that it would be nice of her to help me. The rest of the ride to my house was spent in silence.

11.content:
Melissa's parents pulled up to the two story blue house. The house now looked daunting and empty. My first thought was it was now a ghost house. A house without my parents in it and filled with dead memories.

Melissa opened the car door while I was still at the back seat. Being more conscious, I knew to let emotions not get the best of me. I watched her open the door with her fragile mind take in consideration all that had happened. Her parents remained sunken to all the events and situations that was unfolding.

"Click" you could hear Melissa finally opening the door. My face was still showed exhaustion, but I managed to get out of the suffocating car with everyone knowing my parents had just died. Finally standing in front of my blue house now seemed gray. The forecast above my head showed that the weatherman predictions of today's weather would call for overcast and some rain. With the gray clouds descending from the roof of the house we all stood questioning if it would be a good idea for us to enter the house.

Turning the knob on the door, the door opened up with squeek to push open. Walking in felt welcoming after noticing it wasn't as dark as outside was. Contiuing my path through the entrance everyone was still sad but relived to be inside. It was better to be inside than standing at the funeral cemetery.

Melissa parents said "You really have a nice house". A silence annoyed my girlfriend and after her parents realized what they just said, they began to feel embarrassed. Her parents were nice married couple who'd stock up on wealth from a life of selling party and fine insurances for houses that belonged to the richest, wealthiest people in the neighborhood. Her parents were actually nice people and when I first met my girlfriend I was relieved to know her parents were nice people.

I followed my girlfriend upstairs to my bedroom to begin packing my stuff. Melissa hand turned to my desk and she picked up a newspaper. "Why is there a newspaper here?" Frantically I rushed to see what she was talking about. "October 9th-, Parents died of unknown causes and with unidentified disease" I freaked. All stomach bubbles were jumping in my stomach as I tried to remain calm enough to know what is that I needed to tell my girlfriend next. Melissa stood with her head cropped with her hair laying on her shoulders and asked "Why would this mysteriously be here with today date and the newspaper hasn't even arrived yet?". "I don't know Melissa but you can not tell anyone about this." I could see the tears trying to form to saturate in the light but I remained still and firm for her sake.

"I honestly don't know why people can't know about this." "Melissa, it will multiply if we tell or not." They both stood waiting to come up with a plan and fast. He tucked one hand below his pocket and the other manage to go in his left pocket. "I think we should go far into it and talk to the chief there."

Melissa knew it was coming. She was waiting for him to say so any minute. "Okay we got to go. We gotta try this out and see if we can save everyone.", Melissa said while bagging cloths in one suitcase.

They could hear the parents downstairs moving their paste below so they knew it was time for them to hurry.

"Time to go." Melissa were getting ready to leave. "Alright Mom I be back in a week.", said Melissa in a loud voice from her boyfriends room.

BOOOM! SMACK! The loud noise echoed and almost seem to paralyze everyone next move. "Eddy!" Melissa Mom screamed. "What the" both of them ran down. The disease was showing in her dad's face and pale was revealing he didn't have a fighting chance.

SMACK. I grabbed my bag and headed out, grabbing my girlfriend with me. Back into the forest we had our cloths that would be descent for jungle hiking. "Alright here it is Melissa. We have to get through this path to reach him." Melissa started to know that this may be the last warm tear she has strolling down her face. "I don't know if the man out here are going to let us it." "We have to Melissa, inless you want your Mom to be next!"

A orange-reddish plant with long green stem glowed by the infested poison oak tree. I grabbed my blade my father gave me on my 14th birthday and opened to stretch the blade. The cutting of the steam seemed to echoed, and a monkey seem to be alarming the jungle we were in a remote area. Rushing through the tall grass the flower was put inside my back pack behind me.

The pathway became visible once again and we were relieved. "Why didn't they tell us the disease could be cured." "Who knows Melissa." It was probably the best idea to protect this only flower left."

"Hey what are yall doing here" said the chief.

"Nothing, we were just going on a hike." I said trying to sound untouched by the sudden events. The chief seen Melissa face and that she managed to grinned to make everything look normal as possible.

"We have to hurry before the secret services show up with guns" Melissa said, as she was already eagered to leave. "Alright lets go." The chief didn't think to ask anything else and went on walking to where the plant was once at.

After an hour walk we managed to take the plant observatory to where they could liquefy the plant and make a medicine.

“That sounds nice,” my voice cracked with sleep, “let me get dressed and I will be down in a minute.” I said to her, the sound of sadness was clear in the tone.
I sat up as she left the room, her sundress fluttering every so lightly as she walked. I swung my legs over the edge of the queen sized bed and set my feet heavily onto the red oak floor. I moved slowly to my dresser trying to shake the tiredness that gripped me. I figured it was because of the depression, and the physical fatigue that I still haven’t gotten over from the virus that I had. I lazily put on a t-shirt and a loose-fitting pair of faded blue jeans. I walked to the door slowly as I tried to retain my balance. I found myself thinking if this virus wasn’t over but I brushed it off as I reached the door and my balance returned to a normal state. I walked through the hallway that overlooked the first floor. I stopped suddenly as a wave of nausea passed over me. I collapsed to the ground and shortly after blacked out.
When I awoke I was shocked to find that something had changed.

121.content:
My eyes opened and I stared at the red-oak floor. Something was different, but I couldn’t place my finger on what it was. I slowly sat up and looked around. My jaw dropped in shock. Everything around me was a hundred times bigger. The hallway was like a football field, stretching for a mile in each direction. The ceiling was high above me, as expansive as the sky. I felt something underneath my hand and I looked to see a hair, probably only six inches long, but to me it looked like a golden rope. What had happened? I couldn’t be more than four inches tall! A loud buzzing filled my head as something large and black fly in front of my vision. A fly landed in front of me, big enough to be a cat. I stared into its horrific multi-paneled eyes and screamed. The fly disappeared and I sat there panting in fear. Suddenly the ground began to shake and I heard a familiar jingling sound. I turned to see what looked like hell bounding towards me. My sister’s black Labrador, Marco, was galloping across the wooden floor, his tongue hanging out and his ears flopping. I yelled in terror, closing my eyes and covering my head with my hands, expecting to feel sharp canines cutting into my skin or claws tearing me to shreds. Instead, the rumbling stopped and I felt hot breath blowing on me. I opened my eyes to see Marco with his paws to the ground, tail wagging, expecting me to play. Stupid dog. I was just about to shoo him off when an idea popped into my head. I needed to get to Melissa and maybe Marco could help me. When my little sister was born, she was blind until the age of five. My parents had gotten her Marco to help her get around and to fetch someone when she needed something. Marco would respond to most commands. If I told him to find Melissa, he would find Melissa.
I looked around and spotted one of Marco’s toys. It was one of those short ropes, the ones that are used for tug-of-war. I ran to the toy and grabbed onto its thick fibers. When I thought I was secure enough I called out to Marco, “Marco! Here boy! Take me to Melissa!” As soon as the words left my mouth I knew that this was a bad idea. Marco grabbed the toy, showering me in slobber, and flew down the hallway. I screamed as I swung back and forth, desperately trying to hang on. Marco trampled down the stairs, my body vibrating violently at the force. At the last few steps, the dog leapt and landed on the Persian carpet roughly. He stumbled a bit and that was enough for me to loose my grip. The fibers of the rope toy slipped through my fingers and I tumbled onto the Persian rug. I groaned and sat up, just to see Marco run into the kitchen without me. Melissa appeared, holding Marco’s toy. The dog jumped up and down in excitement. My girlfriend opened the sliding glass window to the backyard and threw the toy out. Marco leapt after it and Melissa closed the door. Marco came up to the door with his tail wagging, but stopped when he couldn’t get in. He dropped the toy as he barked to be let back in. Man, that dog was stupid.
~Torch~

I turned and looked back at Melissa. To my luck, she began walking towards the stairs. I called out her name, trying to get her attention. Unfortunately, she was singing a happy tune and my shouts were drowned out. Her voice was sweet and beautiful, but now more than ever I wished that she would just shut up. I stood up as she got closer. Maybe I could jump onto her leg or something. Just then, the phone rang and Melissa turned to answer it. She went to the desk and picked up the cordless. “Hello, Smithson residence,” Melissa said into the phone. I began to run towards her; I needed her help. “Oh, hi. Of course. Yes, I’ll do that. Just that? Nothing else? Okay, I’ll take care of it.” She hung up the phone just as I stopped, panting at one of the legs of the desk. I wished I wasn’t so out of shape. I had no more breath to call out to her and I cursed to myself as she walked away. She walked to the edge of the stairs and called up, “John, I’m heading to the store to pick up a few things. Breakfast is ready. I’ll see you soon.” If only I had waited a little longer; maybe she would have seen me. I groaned in frustration and looked around. Melissa’s bag was near the desk. It could be my chance to gain her attention. I sprinted to the bag and climbed in, falling amongst the various vanities of a teenage girl’s purse. Her mascara and eyeliner fell on top of me as I struggled to gain my footing amongst the scattered objects. I pushed the giant makeup off of me as I felt the bag being lifted up and I fell deeper into the pile. I could sense the swinging of the bag as I unsuccessfully tried to stand back up. I heard the front door open and close with a familiar click. The jingling of keys told me that Melissa was opening the door of the car. Just as I heard the car door open, my stomach was forced into my throat as Melissa tossed the bag onto the seat. For a brief moment, I was weightless, floating among the contents of the purse. Then, with a horrible crunch, all the force came down on me as the bag hit the seat and everything went black.
My head was throbbing when I finally came to. I tried to sit up but a wave of nausea caused me to lie back down. Slowly, the pain subsided and I sat up, leaning against something soft but firm. It was dark wherever I was at and the sound of conversing was all around me. I lifted my hand and began to rub my head. My fingers brushed over a spot on my forehead that sent extreme pain through my brain. I had a huge gash there; no wonder my head hurt so much. Who knew makeup could be so deadly? I listened to the voices outside. From what I heard, I was probably still in Melissa’s bag and she was at school. That means I was out for a whole day! I needed to get her attention.
~Torch~

From what I could overhear, the school day was reaching its end. That makeup really did a number on me, didn’t it? Maybe it was more than just the makeup...

Can’t think about that right now. Pretty soon, Melissa will be back in her car, and when it’s just the two of us, that’s when I’ll make my move. In the meantime, I need to keep busy. I have to prepare. I feel my way around this dark purse for something soft, and I find some kind of makeup sponge or blotter or whatever they call it. The important thing is, it’s soft enough that I can shield my head.

Good thing, too. My stomach sinks as Melissa lifts me and this purse high into the air. Things tumble around a bit, but I avoid any further injuries, mostly, and I have a moment to reflect on the ridiculousness of this whole thing. I’m tiny in my girlfriend’s purse, and her casual actions are wreaking havoc all around me.

It’s frustrating how little control I have over anything anymore, just like with my...

The motion finally stops. I poke my head out through a gap in the zipper and see that I’ve been plopped onto the passenger’s seat in her car. I turn to the side, and--

Wow, I forgot how gigantic she looks to me now. Wow. Wow, she’s really beautiful. She’s even more beautiful than at regular size. How is that?

She’s switching her CD. Now’s my chance!

“Melissa!” I shout.

She turns her head from side to side, curious and hopeful. “...John?”

“Down here! Look at the purse!”

She does, and just when I thought her eyes couldn’t get any larger... “Oh my God!” she yells.

Unfortunately, she yells while her windows are open.

An outside passer-by leans down by Melissa’s window. “Everything okay there, Melissa?”

Hey...That’s Marie out there! A gigantic Marie, but my still good friend Marie.

Should I let her in on my, um, condition?

I hadn’t seen John since yesterday morning and I had really begun to worry. When I got back from the store, the breakfast I had made had not been eaten and John was nowhere to be found. It was like he just disappeared. I searched the entire house but found no trace of him. He didn’t even write a note. I tried calling his cell phone but all I got was an answering machine. After driving to all of his favorite hangouts, I came up empty. Where could he have gone? He had just lost his entire family and I knew that he felt that it was his fault, but he wasn’t one to go off and do something stupid or dangerous. I just hoped that he was alright. Ronald Terrepet, the best friend of John’s father, had called when John didn’t show up for their weekly coffee outing. When I told him that John was nowhere to be found, he was concerned, but wasn’t going to do anything drastic. “If he’s not back by tomorrow,” Ronald said, “then we need to worry.”
I woke up that morning in John’s house, hoping that he would show up, but it was just me and Marco. The only thing I could think of doing was going to school and seeing if anyone there knew anything about John’s whereabouts. I walked through the hallways, my favorite purse by my side. I probably looked like a wreck, considering I didn’t sleep at all the night before; I was too caught up in worry. One of my friends, Katy, walked past me.
“Hi, Melissa. Whoa! Are you ok? You look horrible!”
“I’m fine,” I lied, putting on my best smile. I walked past a window and glanced at my reflection. I did look horrible. Maybe I would put on some makeup to cover up the mess that I was. I walked into the girls’ bathroom and stood in front of the mirror, placing my purse on top of the sink. I opened my bag and began rummaging through the junk for some mascara. The last time I had been in my purse was two days ago. My fingers wrapped around my mascara, but just as they did, I felt something on the top of my hand. I thought something had tipped over and I began to draw out my hand, but whatever it was, it was still attached. I could feel it pinching my skin. I pulled my hand out and shrieked in surprise, gripping the sink to keep myself from falling over. The object on my hand fell back into my bag and I scrambled to look into my purse, trying to convince myself that I hadn’t seen what I just thought I saw. I tentatively opened my bag and looked inside. My heart skipped a beat.
There was John, lying on my wallet, staring up at me. He couldn’t have been more than four inches tall. I could see the fear on his face, the rampant emotions that he must have been feeling. I wondered if I looked the same.
~Torch~

John soon answered that question for me.
He screamed as he snapped back into consciousness, startled by the sudden feeling of pain. With his right arm he clutched his side, whimpering. He opened his eyes and looked up at me in fear, his breaths quick and strained.
“John, it’s okay, Tracy’s gone,” I said, trying to calm him down. Oh, gosh, I couldn’t imagine what he was feeling. He clenched his teeth in pain, but seemed to relax a little.
“M…my rib is broken,” he said thickly through his bloody nose. “It hurts like hell.”
“I need to get you to the hospital,” I said softly, motioning to pick him up.
“No!” he yelled, surprising me. He looked at me sadly. “You don’t know what they’ll do to me. I can’t go there.”
“John, you’re severely injured. I have to do something!”
“Just take me home. I have some first aid stuff there that we can use. Please, I don’t want anyone else to know about this right now.”
“Okay, but I don’t want to pick you up and cause you more pain.”
“I’ll be ok. It’s just my rib and nose that’s broken. I think my shoulder is only out of place.” He said this with confidence, but he looked frightened as I slowly began to slide my hand underneath him. I did my best not to hurt him, but he still let out a sharp groan when I touched his torso.
“Sorry,” I whispered to him, feeling horrible, but he only nodded in response. I carefully stood up, trying to keep my hand from moving too much when a thought entered my head: how was I supposed to hide him? Then I remembered my coat. I had taken it with me into the bathroom and laid it on the floor next to the sink. Since it was cold outside I would need it anyway, and it was the perfect way to hide John without hurting him. I walked over to the sink and picked up my coat, sliding my free arm into it before slowly sliding my hand with John into the sleeve. I didn’t pull my arm all the way through; instead I kept my hand hidden in the cuff of the sleeve.
With my purse slung over my shoulder, I walked out of the bathroom and into the busy hallway full of students. Nobody said anything to me as I walked past and I was grateful for that. I made it outside without an incident and to my car within a minute. As soon as I sat down in the driver’s seat, I started the car and turned the heat on high. I gripped Melissa’s palm as I tried to withstand the pain. She responded to my touch by stroking my hair with her index finger. I always liked it when she touched my hair; it felt good and it relaxed me. The touch took my mind off the agony for a moment and I could focus on the other things around me.
Above me was Melissa’s beautiful face, stained red with tears as she switched from looking at me to focusing on the road. Her long hair was like ropes of gold that hung down on her shoulders. I just wanted to reach out and let them run through my fingers. The gloomy sky flashed past as I looked out the windshield and side window. I could see the cold, wooden skeletons of the trees fly past, many covered with the year’s first snow. The only thing that was still green was the pine trees and their dark complexion. I could feel the engine of the car rumbling underneath me and could hear the click, click, click as Melissa signaled to turn. She unlocked the door and stepped inside, and the familiar feeling of my house washed over me. It was good to be home and away from that school. But I didn't know if we were the only ones there.

I could see the flashes of hatred flash her in eyes and it was this day that I knew my poor gerbil was going to die.

It was then that I realized that the zipper was open.

Do you know how much money we could make off of him? We’ll be rich!” I gulped. This was bad; this was really bad.

Never before had I been so scared. I was in some serious trouble.
<Melissa>
I could have screamed in total panic at that moment. John was gone and I didn’t know where. To make matters worse, he was smaller than my hairbrush! I paced back and forth in front of his stairs, trying to calm myself and think of what to do. He must have gotten lost at school, which was not a very good place to be. But how? Unless…
The phone rang and I jumped in surprise. I answered it with shaking hands. “Hello?” “Melissa? It’s me, John.” I closed my eyes and breathed a sigh of relief, and then I noticed the tone of his voice. “Are you ok? Where are you?” “I…I can’t say.” His voice was shaking with obvious fear. “What do you mean? What’s going on, John?” “Melissa, I need to come up with 5 million dollars by 12 PM tonight or they’ll kill me.” “Who will kill you?” “I can’t tell you. Please call Ron. I don’t know what to do.” “John…John!” He didn’t answer me. Another voice came on the line. “If you want to see him again,” the voice said, “bring the money to the central park by the oak tree to the north. Don’t call the police.” Then the phone went dead. I felt like a statue as the phone slowly slipped out of my hands and fell to the floor. All of the blood had drained from my face and head. I suddenly felt weak and nauseous. What was I going to do? Only John had access to that money and it wouldn’t be his for another 4 months. Slowly I picked the phone back up and began dialing the number.
~Torch~
12113221.title: Kidnapped

121132211.content:
<Ronald>
As I sat there, the general chaos of the office surrounding me, my mind wandered to the not-so-long-ago memories that haunted me. I remember the day that I met Matthew Smithson. We became best friends immediately. He was a brilliant young man, full of energy and potential. He started the now billion dollar business with me as his right-hand man when he was only 18. Together we rose through the business world, developing breakthrough technology, best friends through thick and thin. I remember the day he asked my younger sister, Catherine Terrepet, out on their first date. It seemed such a short time afterwards that they were married. For twenty-five years I helped run the business with my brother-in-law. They had two children, John and Jenny, making me a proud uncle. I loved them like my own children, if I had had any. When I got the call that Matthew, my sister, and my niece had perished from an unknown disease from the Amazon, I was devastated. John was now my only surviving family. I immediately took control of the company, at least until John was old enough to run it on his own. I worried about him, but he had his girlfriend Melissa to take care of him. She was a good girl; I liked her the minute we met. I came to town, expecting to see John at the weekly coffee outing we usually had, but he didn’t show up. When I called Melissa and she said that he was missing, I was concerned, but he had gone through so much in a short period of time. I would give him time to recover. He would call me when he was ready.
I always carried a special cell phone in my pocket. When Matthew was alive, he would call me on this cell phone, knowing that I would always answer. Now, as the phone rang, I knew that it could only be one person. I flipped open the phone and answered it, “Hello, John.” But it wasn’t John; it was Melissa. I was surprised that she had called me. This couldn’t be good. “Melissa, what’s wrong?” “I’m sorry to bother you, Ron, but something has happened to John. He’s been kidnapped, and whoever did it is demanding a 5 million dollar ransom by midnight or they’ll kill him.” My heart skipped a beat. I was silent for a brief moment before answering. “I’m coming to the house. Don’t do anything until I get there.”
Melissa was waiting for me at the door. She held it open as I walked in. I could tell that she was worried, her whole body was tense. “Tell me everything you know about John,” I said to her. She took a deep breath and then looked at me with almost pleading eyes. “Before I start I need to tell you something that I didn’t mention before, but you have to believe me.” I looked at her curiously. I had no idea what she was referring to. “John…kind of shrunk.” I was taken aback. “Come again?” “John is only four inches tall.” I just blinked and stared at her. “Is this some kind of joke?” “No, I’m serious! I don’t know what happened, but I found him in my purse at school.” John…shrunk? Was that even possible? I studied Melissa. There was a seriousness about her. She wasn’t one to joke about such things. She watched me anxiously, obviously hoping that I believed her. There was no doubt in her eyes.
“I’m not lying,” she said. “John is in some serious trouble.” “It’s ok; I believe you. Here’s what we’re going to do…”
~Torch~
121132211.title: Uncle Ronald

1211322111.content:
<John>
Trapped. That’s how I felt. That’s how I was. Bound by duct tape across my chest and a cloth to gag me, I was immobile inside one of Ryan’s rancid pockets. It stank of smoke, sweat, and marijuana. The smell alone could suffocate a person and I had to breathe it in as the only air supply. My head throbbed horribly where it had been cut. The recent beatings I had endured had reopened the wound. Hot blood was slowly trickling down the side of my face. I shivered, not from cold but from fear. I had heard what the gang was planning to do with me after they got the money. It scared the crap out of me. I didn’t even know if Melissa would show up. Thoughts of horrid deaths filled my mind. I tried to push them away as I listened to what was going on outside.
“It’s almost 12,” I heard one voice say. “What if she doesn’t show?” “Oh, she’ll show alright,” Ryan said, he deep voice reverberating in my chest. I heard the cocking of multiple guns. Each member of the gang carried a pistol. I just hoped that they wouldn’t use them. “Shhh! Someone’s coming!” I heard the faint crunch of grass as the person approached. Ryan walked forward. “Did you come alone?” he demanded. “Yes,” said the person. I recognized them immediately as Melissa. A wave of relief ran through me. She did come to save me! But there was also fear. I couldn’t bear to see her get hurt.
“Give us the money.” “Not until I know that John is alright.” Ryan chuckled and thrust his fist into his pocket. I took in a sharp breath as his fingers squeezed tightly around my chest. He roughly pulled me out and I found myself falling through the air for a brief moment. I hit something soft and cool: fresh grass. It broke my fall enough to keep me from breaking any bones, but I was in pain from the impact. I rolled over onto my back just as something pushed down on my chest and legs. Ryan had placed his foot on me. I wasn’t being crushed but it was hard to breathe. I could smell the grass and see its blades as big as flat trees. I looked up to see Melissa about ten feet away, holding a silver briefcase. She looked at me with fear and worry.
“Let him go!” “Not until we have the money.” Melissa bit her lip and slowly held out the briefcase. One of the gang members grabbed it from her but Ryan didn’t step off of me. “I gave you the money now let him go!” Ryan laughed. “Sorry, toots; we have other plans for him.” He lifted his foot from me and prepared to slam it down. I closed my eyes and whimpered, waiting for the crushing blow that would kill me. “I wouldn’t do that if I were you,” a different voice said. I opened my eyes to see Ron with a double barreled shotgun aiming directly at Ryan. My heart leapt with joy. “If you harm him I swear I’ll pull the trigger.” Ryan chortled and pulled out his pistol. “Really old man? You’re going to mess with me?” Every member of the gang aimed their weapons at Ron. My uncle just smiled.
The noise of numerous weapons cocking filled the area. Uniformed men wearing bullet-proof vests and carrying semi-automatic guns surrounded the gang. The letters S.W.A.T. were stamped on their chests. The gang was outnumbered, five to one. “Whoa! Whoa! Whoa!” Ryan yelled backing away. “I told you not to call the police!” “I didn’t,” Melissa responded. “Besides, this isn’t the police.” “I strongly advise you to put down your weapons and step away from my nephew,” Ron said, still smiling. One by one the gangsters put down their guns and raised their hands in the air. Ryan cursed fluently under his breath. A S.W.A.T. member grabbed the briefcase from the gang and handed it to Ron. “Thank you, boys,” Ron said. “By the way,” he opened up the briefcase, revealing nothing. “It was empty.” The gang was led away, handcuffed, to a police car on the street.
I turned to see Melissa kneel down beside me. Gently, she undid the cloth wrapped around my mouth. “Melissa,” was the first word I said. There was no way to describe how relieved I was. “It’s ok, John. You’re safe.” She slid her arm underneath my head and back, lifting me into the air. As I looked at her caring face, my vision began to blur and numbness surrounded me. I closed my eyes as I was consumed in darkness.
~Torch~
1211322111.title: Saved, for now

12113221111.content:
I woke on something soft and warm. I was lying on my back with my eyes closed. My entire body ached with the abuse I had taken over the last few days. Slowly the memories of what had happened came back to me. I opened my eyes and blinked at the light. Far above me was the plain white ceiling of my room. To the left of me was my nightstand and to the right was my dresser, a hundred times bigger than normal. I was lying on my bed, covered part ways with a thin sheet. I gingerly sat up, sore all over. My shirt that I had been wearing had been taken off and the various cuts on my bare chest and arms had been bandaged up. I ran a hand over my forehead, feeling the cloth covering the gash on my head. I was still wearing my pants, but my shoes and socks had been taken off.
Suddenly, the door to my room opened and someone walked in. It was my butler, Herald. He was tall and skinny with a very sophisticated demeanor about him, but he was always very kind. He looked down at me without any shock or surprise. “Ah, master John! I’ll send in Melissa for you.” With that he left the room, leaving me a little stunned. A wonderful smell wafted in from the open door. I inhaled deeply as my mouth watered at the familiar scent. The thought of warm blueberry pancakes with eggs and bacon filled my mind, making my stomach growl. I hadn’t eaten for a while. Melissa appeared in the doorway, carrying a tray with breakfast on it. Her warm smile brightened my mood as she came and sat down on the bed. “Good morning, John. How are you feeling?” I rubbed my shoulders. “Sore, very sore.” She nodded sadly. “I’m just glad you’re alive.” She placed the tray in front of me and sat Indian-style across from me. I eyed the steaming platter of food eagerly. Melissa began tearing off small chunks and handing them to me. I wolfed them down, savoring each delicious morsel. Together, Melissa and I ate breakfast. When we finished, Melissa put the tray on the nightstand and Herald silently walked in and took care of it. I hadn’t felt so satisfied in a long time.
Melissa slowly stretched herself out on the bed, lying with her face towards me. I still couldn’t get over how big she was compared to me. “What happened?” I asked. “All I remember is seeing you.” “You passed out, probably from exhaustion. We took you home and Ron fixed you up. You’ve been out for a little over a day now.” “Where is Ron?” “He’s making a phone call. I suspect that he’ll come in soon.” Just then, Uncle Ron appeared in the doorway. He had a cell phone up to his ear and was talking in his ‘business-as-usual’ voice. “Uh-huh…great. We’ll do that. Yes. Thank you…you too; good-bye.” He hung up the phone and kneeled at the side of the bed. “That was an old colleague of mine. He might be able to help you out.” I looked away bitterly. “I don’t think anyone can help me out.” “John, we’ll get you back to normal somehow, I promise.” For the first time in days, I smiled. There was still something to live for; I hadn’t lost everything. “Thanks, Ron.” “The only problem is that he lives in Europe. We’ll have to take the jet to reach him. It’s up to you.”
~Torch~
12113221111.title: Home Again

121132211112.content:
My mind went back to all the times I had been on a plane. It was a common occurrence for me but ever since I was little I’ve gotten severe motion sickness. Not only that, I’ve had a few cases of altitude sickness. I always had to take medicine before I went on a plane. I couldn’t imagine what it would do to me at this size. “I don’t think that’s a good idea, Ron. You know what I’m like on airplanes.” “Hmmm, you’re right. Maybe I can get my friend to come here. I’ll call him back.” He walked out of the room, pulling out his cell phone. I could hear him talking as he walked down the hallway. I turned and looked back at Melissa. She had propped her head on her hands and was looking down at me. “So what exactly happened to you, do you know?” I shook my head. “I was walking down the hallway to join you for breakfast and I passed out. I woke up like this.” I looked down at my hands. Everything about me was the same, just not my size. “I think that the virus did this to me.” “But how is that possible?” “I don’t know. I’m not a disease expert.” “I think something more than just a disease caused this. It just doesn’t make sense.” “But who would do this to me? What can anyone gain from making me as small as a mouse?” “I don’t know, but hopefully Ron’s friend can fix this. I don’t want you to be stuck like this forever.” I looked up at her with a smile. “What? You don’t like having a boyfriend you can keep in your pocket?” She giggled. “You are really cute. It would be a lot cooler if we knew for sure that this isn’t permanent.” “Yeah. I don’t want to have to adjust my entire life to this.” “Oh, that reminds me…” Melissa stood up and crawled off the bed. She went over to my dresser and picked something up off of it. “Ron had some clothes made for you.” She set the articles in front of me and I looked with amazement at the assortment. It was exactly like regular clothes, just made to fit me. One T-shirt even had my favorite football team’s logo. Uncle Ron’s attentiveness to detail never ceased to surprise me. I picked up one of the shirts and pulled it over my head. It fit me just right and was fairly comfortable. “That’s cool.” “Your shoes are also there if you want them. You’re old shirt was kind of ripped up by the gang. Ron saved it to run some tests on it.” Ron came in the room again, cell phone on hand. “He said he’d be able to take his equipment here. He’ll be here by tonight. I’m sending the private jet to pick him up.” Ron got a worried look on his face. “I have to go back to the company for a few hours. Will you be alright here?” “He’s fine, I’ll take care of him,” Melissa said. “Besides, we have Herald in case we need help.” Herald walked past the room just at that moment. “Whatever you say Mistress Melissa.” I chuckled at his vague sense of humor. “I guess,” Ron said. “I’ll have my cell phone if you need me.” He turned and walked out of the room. Melissa placed her hand next to me and I crawled onto her open palm. I tried to refrain from gripping her fingers tightly. I still wasn’t used to be lifted into the air like that. Melissa carried me out into the hallway. I heard a distressed barking coming from my sister’s old room. I guess Marco had been locked up. Stupid dog.
<Ronald>
I took a deep breath as I drove to the office. So much had happened in the last week, it was physically and mentally draining. When we confronted the gang and I saw John for the first time, I was more afraid than I had been in a long time. Nothing like that had ever happened before. He was so small, only big enough to fit in my palm. When he was unconscious and I held him, I was afraid I was going to break him. My last living relative and he had to have this happen to him. I could only hope and pray that my old friend could help him.
~Torch~
121132211112.title: Staying away from the flying death trap

1211322111121.content:
<Melissa>
I held John in my hands as Ron drove to the lab. Ron’s colleague had arrived with all his equipment and had set up in one of the company’s labs. We were going to see if he could help John. As we pulled into the parking lot, a strange man in a lab coat came out to greet us. “Good to see you, Caesar,” Ron said as he shook the man’s hand. Caesar was tall and lanky, with disheveled silver-gray hair and lopsided glasses. He wasn’t very old, no older than Ron in fact. “I’m glad I could be of service,” Caesar replied. “Now where is this nephew of yours, Joshua?” “Actually, his name is John and Melissa has him.” I held out my hands to Caesar who bent down to inspect John. “Hmmm. This is very interesting. I’ll have to run some tests on him.” “Tests?” I asked nervously. “Oh, nothing that will hurt little Jacob.” “John,” Ron corrected him. “Yes, yes of course.” Caesar walked into the building, muttering something to himself. He seemed a little…distracted, as if there was a lot on his mind. Ron seemed to read my expression. “Don’t worry; he’s always like that. He’s very brilliant, but he tends to forget things really easily.” We followed the scientist into the building and down a flight of stairs to a door marked ‘Restricted’. A young man in a lab coat was there, holding the door open for us. “This is my assistant, Nathan,” Caesar said. Nathan was a little stockier, with short sandy brown hair and thick eyebrows. His hooked nose and slight frown made him look a little angry. I walked past him suspiciously. Something about him made me…cautious.
“Just set Jack down on that table, would you?” I gently placed John on a counter next to a variety of complicated instruments. John gave me one nervous glance before looking at Caesar. “Now how exactly did this occur?” Caesar said while pulling on a pair of gloves. John explained what had happened to him while Caesar listened intently. “A disease? I have never heard of such a thing before. This is very intriguing.” He reached over the counter and grabbed what I recognized as a Geiger counter. He ran the sensor over John’s body. John flinched a little. I could tell he was intimidated. “No radiation. I’ll have to check his electrical pulses and maybe draw some blood.” Caesar lifted a briefcase from the floor and opened it to reveal an assortment of needles. Caesar pulled out one particular needle, two inches long. John hastily backed up and tripped over a pair of tweezers. “There is no way you’re putting that in me!” he yelled. Caesar looked at him in surprise. “Of course not! I just thought of how I needed this for one of my experiments. See I’m taking a group of…” “Caesar, focus,” Ron said. Caesar blinked. “Of course, yes, that’s right.” He put the needle away and pulled out a smaller one. This one was only a half-inch long and was extremely thin. Still, I couldn’t imagine what it would be like to John. “Alright, Jordan; hold out your arm.” John obeyed, his eyes never leaving that needle. With the help of a magnifying glass and with exact precision that I hadn’t expected him to have, Caesar placed the needle on John’s arm and poked it into his vein. John twitched but stayed still. Slowly, the flow of John’s blood began to fill the needle. Caesar only took as much blood as in proportion to someone full-sized donating blood. It was a miniscule amount, but it was something. John breathed out as Caesar pulled out the needle. He had been holding his breathe. Nathan handed John a small piece of gauze to stop the flow of blood from his arm. Caesar took a small sample of the blood and placed it underneath what looked like a microscope on steroids. The thing was as big as a person. With help from Nathan, Caesar used a computer to operate the machine. A moving picture of John’s blood filled the computer screen. His individual red blood cells could be seen. “Oh my!” Caesar said after examining the blood for about a minute. “What is it?” Ron asked as he moved to stand behind Caesar. “I’ve never seen anything like this!” Caesar magnified the picture on one single blood cell. It looked like a regular blood cell, but…
“Something’s attached to it,” Ron exclaimed. “But what could it be?” “I have only seen this in one other instance, and it was an experiment that went horribly wrong. Those are nanobots.” “Nanobots? That kind of technology hasn’t been created yet!” “Apparently someone figured it out and used it on little Juan here.” “That would explain the so-called ‘disease’ that John had. The nanobots were trying to bind with his blood. I wonder if that’s how Matthew and my sister and niece were killed.” “How did nanobots get inside me?” John asked. Caesar looked at him. “The only way this could have occurred is if someone injected the bots into your bloodstream. This was a planned event.”
“What are we going to do?” I asked. Caesar was quiet for a moment. “Well, the only way to reverse this is to take control of the nanobots themselves, which is almost impossible if you weren’t the one who programmed them in the first place.” “So there’s no hope for me?” John said in despair. “Oh, there’s hope, it’ll just be a long and difficult process, but it can be done.” Ron placed a hand on Caesar’s shoulder. “Thank you for this, Caesar. You are welcome to stay at the mansion for as long as you wish.” “It would probably be a good idea to get some sleep. There’s nothing else that can be done tonight.”
<John>
I laid in my bed, tossing and turning, trying to catch a little bit of shuteye. I just couldn’t get to sleep. I kept thinking about who would want to do this to me. Why would anyone try to shrink me and my family? It just didn’t make any sense. A noise caused me to sit up and look towards my door. Nathan was entering my room. He and Caesar were both staying at the house. Something about the look on his face told me that he wasn’t here for peace. I scrambled away as he stretched out his hand for me. I tried to reach the buzzer near me that would alert Melissa or Ron if I needed anything, but Nathan grabbed me before I could reach it. His fingers crammed my arms against my chest and squeezed me with enough force to make it hard to breath. I squirmed against the hand, desperate to get free. I could see that we were exiting my room and entering my sister’s old bedroom. Nathan shoved his thumb into my mouth to keep me from shouting for help. Finally, he released me and I sat gasping in his hand. “Ugh! It smells in here!” he complained and opened the window. The cool night breeze ruffled my hair and clothes. I looked up in fear at his face. He was smiling with a wicked gleam in his eyes. I knew that this wasn’t going to end well. Just as Nathan reached out his other hand for me, a loud bark rang out through the room. Marco jumped from his spot on the carpet and latched his jaws onto Nathan’s calf. Nathan yelled in pain and I finally felt a bit of appreciation for that dog, but then I felt myself flying through the air. Nathan had flung his arms back, releasing me and causing me to go flying through the open window. As I saw the dark green of the grass below, only one thing was on my mind: That stupid dog! Even when he tried to save me he was the cause of my doom.
~Torch~
1211322111121.title: Discoveries

12113221111211.content:
Cold, brisk air whirled past me as I fell through the air. I caught glimpses of my house and the dark trees growing next to it as I tumbled, cart wheeling towards the ground. My life and all of my memories, both good and bad, flashed before my eyes in a split second. So much had happened in the past week. This would be a fitting end to my miserable existence. My body turned so that I was looking up into the night sky. I saw a glimpse of the silver stars, so far away yet so close. The moon shone down on me like a solemn friend. I spotted the big dipper, forever fixed in the heavens, and I wondered if the God of the universe cared about all that had happened to me. I prayed that I would see my family again.
My feet struck the ground first, shattering under the impact. The bones in my calf and thigh snapped and my legs flared outward, the bones sticking through my flesh. There was no time to scream at the excruciating pain, no time to brace for the next wave. My pelvis hit the concrete with a sickening crunch. I literally could hear it fracturing and breaking, like the cracking of ice over a frozen pond. Shards of it stuck into my intestines and what I suspected to be my kidney. Blood spurted out from my hips and a shockwave ran through my body, shattering my ribs. There was a sharp pain in my chest as one of my ribs was thrust upwards towards my throat. All of this happened in a split second. I rolled along the ground as my world became a curtain of red. Pain like nothing I had ever felt before consumed me, but I was still alive. A sickening feeling welled up in my throat as blood poured from an unknown rib wound. My throat gurgled and convulsed as I choked for breath, but my lungs were utterly ruined. My heart fluttered weakly as I struggled for life, but it was no use. I closed my eyes and surrendered to the complete darkness.
~Torch~
12113221111211.title: The Concrete Grave

12113221111212.content:
As I tumbled through the air, I couldn’t help but think of the old paratrooper song that I knew. He hit the ground the sound was splat the blood went spurting high… I wondered what my internal organs would look splattered over the ground, but I didn’t want to wait to find out. I flailed my arms about, desperate to grab onto something, anything. As if in answer to my prayer, a sharp pain hit my back and I heard the snapping of something that I hoped wasn’t my ribs. A swirl of brown and dark green filled my vision as I crashed through a tangled web of branches. The wind was knocked out of me as I hit twig after twig, but at least I was slowing down. Finally, I came to a complete, and very painful, stop as I hit a large branch. With a groan I rolled over and blinked, trying to get the white spots out of my eyes. Slowly I sat up and looked around. I was in the large oak tree, growing right next to the house. How the heck was I supposed to get out of here? At least I wasn’t dead.
A soft rustling noise alerted my attention. I turned to see an owl perched on the same branch that I was on. The bird looked at me with its luminous yellow eyes. I immediately froze. This was not good. The owl tilted its head back and forth in the characteristic sharp movements of birds. Then to my horror, it spread its wings and swooped upon me before I could react. I screamed as its talons wrapped around my body and lifted me into the air. Pain exploded from my side as one of the birds claws pierced through my skin. I could feel the warm blood soaking my shirt. I fell limp, hoping to fool the bird into thinking that I was dead, knowing that birds of prey crush their victims with their claws. The night air whipped past me as I looked down. I gulped at the enormous height we seemed to be at. The roofs of houses passed underneath as the owl flew silently towards an unknown destination. Suddenly, the bird went into a steep dive and I resisted the urge to grab onto its toes as we descended. Gracefully, it landed on the flat roof of a building next to what I suspected to be an air duct. Maybe I could use that to escape. The bird ruffled its feathers once before peering down at me with its large eyes. I remained as still as I could, hoping the bird took me for dead instead of dealing a killing blow. The owl, satisfied with the preparations of its meal, lifted its foot and bent down to begin pecking out my guts. Immediately, I scrambled to my feet and sprinted towards the air duct. The owl gave a little screech and flapped after me. I made it into the duct just as the bird hit and rattled the vents. It squawked angrily as it continued to try and peck at me. I slowly backed away from it, panting heavily from fear. I took one step, but my foot found nothing to balance on. I fell into perpetual darkness as I entered the main duct system. My back hit a smooth surface and I slid down a slide-like metal sheet, screaming the entire time. The duct flattened out and I rolled to a stop. I pushed myself up onto my knees and looked around. Faint light was coming from a vent some ways away. I cautiously walked towards it and peered through the metal slants. I gasped when I realized that I was back in the school, possibly the worst place I could be at the time. Now what was I going to do? I needed to get a hold of Melissa or someone, but how? Maybe I could crawl into her locker.
~Torch~
12113221111212.title: On Owl's Wings

choices: She agrees to take you back.
121132211112122.content:
No matter how much I wanted to get help, I was just in too much pain to move. My side was throbbing where the owl had pierced it. I placed my hand against the cut, flinching at the sharp pain, and pressed down to stop the bleeding. I gave out a cry at the agony and quickly pulled away. I sat there gasping. The bleeding would have to stop on its own; it just hurt too much. I lay down with my back against the cold metal of the duct. I shivered from the cool autumn air that blew in from outside. There was not much else that I could do. I might as well try and get some sleep. My mind drifted off as I fell into darkness.
I awoke to the distant sounds of talking and lockers being opened in closed. I groggily sat up and looked around. Bright light was streaming in from the grate next to me, giving me a clear picture of what I looked like. I was a mess; my clothes were torn and I was covered in stinging scratches from that stupid tree. At least it broke my fall, and possibly one of my ribs. A dark red stain covered my shirt on my left side. The bleeding had stop, though the wound still throbbed.
Now I had to come up with an idea of what I was going to do. I couldn’t stay in the vent and wandering out into the hallways in the middle of school was not a very good idea. Maybe I could…
An earsplitting noise broke my train of thought. “What the…?” I managed to say as a gale of wind blew me straight into the metal grating. Someone had turned on the air conditioner, in the middle of November for crying out loud! What kind of idiots ran this school? The force of the air pinned me to the grating as the cold blast blew by me. I struggled frantically to try and get free. I managed to wiggle my way in between the vents and the air shot me out like a rocket. I hit the linoleum floor and rolled to a stop, completely dazed and a little nauseous. Just as my vision returned, a shadow fell over me. I looked to see the underside of a shoe coming down straight towards me. “Ah, s***!” I said as the foot came upon me. Enormous pressure engulfed my entire body and I cried out at the pain. Luckily, whoever it was I realized they were stepping on something and quickly backed off. I heard someone give a short, shrill scream of surprise and then I was lifted into the air. I found myself looking straight into my friend Marie’s face.

Don't worry it’s a variable speed fan and I can control the speed with a remote. The goal of this is to see how fast I can see you go until you puke or your body rips apart from the tension. Doable?” Adrianna asked me as I hung from the rope. She tied the rope onto the fan and I thought about all the things that could go wrong. She could set it on high and I be ripped apart or I my stomach comes out of my mouth and I suffer internally bleeding, or the rope comes free and I get painted like a mural across the wall. I shook my head because none of these were settling situations. I watched Adrianna sit down on the bed and reach for the remote for the fan. She pushed the plus button on the remote once and the fan beeped in response. I was glad I got queasy from amusement park rides because this would definitely go up on the top. The fan beeped once more as it registered the one setting and I felt the vibrations of the electric motor as the fan prepared to spin.
The fan began to spin and I knew I was going to be sick, puking was definitely an option but I didn’t know how when all I have had the last couple of days is crumbs I’ve been fed by various people. I watched as the room began to spin faster and I felt myself lift higher and higher as Adrianna slowly increased the speed. I knew what could happen, I tried to push that to the back of my mind as the contents of my stomach began to churn. I felt light-headedness set in as I was now even with the ceiling fan blades. I could feel the ropes gritting into my legs as they kept me from coming free. The fan increased another notch and I felt a sudden acceleration. I knew this was it as I could taste the bile in my throat, I thought to myself if I could make myself puke but then I tried moving my arms in a controlled manor and realized I didn’t have the muscle to do such a thing. I turned my head over my shoulder to notice that Adrianna’s rope was coming undone. I started to panic when I heard the all to familiar beep and the sudden acceleration of the fan and my stomach finally caved. I spilt the contents of the last two days for meals and for a second it actually looked cool. It was suspended in air and not moving for a split second and then I moved away from it as gravity took over. I opened my eyes for the first time in this ordeal and all I saw was colored blurs whirling past. Just the sound of Adrianna’s voice was enough to make me puke once again. I heard parts of the conversation and it dealt with something about leaving it on or turning it off and keeping her promise.

1211322111121222111211.content:
<John>
The fan kept spinning, sending me through the kaleidoscope of colors. My head was pounding as the blood was forced into it. I groaned in pain as my stomach gave dry heaves, threatening to spew what little bile and digestive juices I had left inside. Finally, the force on me lessoned and the fan began to slow down. The colors formed together into visible shapes and objects as the fan came to a stop. I just hung there upside down, the room spinning with my vision and vomit dripping from my mouth. My head felt like someone was driving spikes into my ears. I made no effort to move; I was sick and drained of energy. My vision had turned red by the time I felt something pull on the string attached to my legs. Adrianna untied the thread and dropped my on the ground. I hit the soft carpet with a thump, glad that it was very shaggy and so it absorbed the contact. I lay there, letting the blood flow back to the rest of my body. My head slowly stopped hurting, but my legs were burning where the string had cut into my skin.
“How was that, little Johnny?” Adrianna sneered. I just stared up at her, knowing that if I said what was on my mind, she would probably kill me then and there. The hatred that coursed through me was unbelievable. Oh, how I wish I could make her pay! But the fear was there, too. This evil witch held my life in her hands and it would be that way for the next three weeks. There was no chance of me escaping.
“Too wonderful for words I see,” she said with a twisted smile. “Don’t worry; I have plenty more in store for you. Unfortunately, you slept most of the day away so we don’t have much time for any more fun. I guess it will have to wait until tomorrow.”
With that she reached down and picked up the string, dangling me in the air as she walked to her room. I had no idea what she was going to do with me now. I just hoped that whatever she had in mind didn’t cause me too much bodily harm. Adrianna entered her room and walked towards her nightstand. From my position I looked down to see a small cage, made for gerbils or other small rodents. It had an opening in the top with which Adrianna dropped me into the cage. She closed the hatch to the cage and then set a jar full of change on top of it.
“There; now you can’t get out. Enjoy your new home little Johnny!” She smiled again and then walked out of the room. I pushed myself up from the layer of shredded wood chips on the bottom of the cage and observed this new prison. It was bare except for a wheel and a small dish with a clear fluid in it that I suspected was water. It smelled like urine and animal fur, which made me guess that it had probably been used before. I sighed in despair; I guess it was better than the other places that she could have put me, but it made me feel so inhuman. I was just a bug to her.
I pulled my legs up close to me and began to undo the string tying them together. I winced as I undid the part that had cut slightly into my skin. Once my legs were free, I stretched them out and took a deep breath of satisfaction. It was then that an amazing smell reached my nose. I stood up on my legs, a little wobbly at first but I was steady enough. I hobbled over to the edge of the cage and looked out the bars, trying to find the source of the amazing smell. Adrianna walked into the room holding a plate of steaming pasta. She deliberately walked past the cage, letting the smell waft over me before she went and sat down on a chair directly across the room from the cage. She pretended not to notice me as she took her pretty little time in eating the pasta. Just the sight of the delicious food made my mouth water. I could just imagine the taste of it, the pleasure I would get as it filled my now empty stomach. My body screamed out for it ‘food! food!’, but I couldn’t satisfy it. I moaned and sat down on the wood chips, knowing that I would get nothing. I watched as Adrianna finished the last of the pasta, scraping the plate clean and licking her lips.
“Mmm! That was delicious!” she mocked. “Oh, I’m sorry! Did I forget to feed my little pet? Let me fix that.” She stood up and grabbed something off of her dresser. I looked up as she stood directly over the cage and dropped something into it. Small objects began raining down on me. I covered my head with my arms until the objects stopped falling and then I looked to see what they were. They were food pellets made for rodents.
“What!? You expect me to eat that?!”
She bent down until her face was as close to the cage as possible. “Mouse food for a mouse of a man!” she giggled. My face flushed in anger as she stood up and sat down on her bed, pulling out her cell phone and occupying herself. Gosh, I hated her! How I wish she would be thrown into burning oil or impaled on a stick like the witch that she is!
I picked up one of the pellets; it was as hard as tree bark, made for the tough incisors of rodent teeth. I couldn’t eat it even if I wanted to. I moaned again and collapsed onto my back on the wood chips, staring up at the cage’s top. This sucked; it couldn’t get much worse than this. Chances were I wasn’t going to survive a few more days with this b****. What had I ever done to deserve this? What did I do to deserve having my family die and then become four inches tall? Hadn’t I helped people throughout my life, donating money and volunteering and stuff? Why was this happening to me?
I wanted to just break down and weep, weep like I had wanted to since I saw the dead bodies of my parents and sister, but I wasn’t going to give that a**hole the satisfaction of seeing me cry. Instead, I closed my eyes, wishing, hoping that somehow, someway, I would get out of this alive.
~Torch~
1211322111121222111211.title: She shuts the fan off.

12113221111212221112111.content:
<John>
A screeching noise awakened me to a dark room. Adrianna’s alarm clock was blaring. I heard a whack as she reached over and turned the device off. I couldn’t see her but I could hear her bed move as she got up and turned on the lights, blinding my still dark-accustomed eyes. Her door opened and closed, leaving me alone in silence for a few minutes before she returned and approached the cage. She was dressed in a jogging suit with jogging pants and sneakers. I didn’t think I was going to like what she had in mind for me.
“Good morning, little Johnny,” she teased. “Did you sleep well in the nice bed that I so thoughtfully made up for you?” I just glared at her, imagining her head being blown off with a shotgun. “We have lots to do today! Are you ready to have some fun?”
“No,” I muttered under my breath. She seemed to have heard me. Adrianna kicked the cage, sending me sprawling backwards.
“That was a rhetorical question, bug. You may not have fun but I will!” She reached over and took the jar of change off of the cage top and opened the little door. I backed away as her giant hand descended upon me but I knew that there was no escape. She pulled me out, holding me tightly in her fist. “You’re going to help me exercise,” she said with that smile of hers that I absolutely hated. She carried me down a flight of stairs to the house’s basement and walked towards a treadmill in the corner of the room. I really didn’t like where this was going. She dropped me on the treadmill track and pulled out a long piece of string similar to the one that had been tied around my legs yesterday.
“Hold up your arms and don’t move,” she commanded me. I reluctantly obeyed, watching as she began to tie the string securely around my wrists and forearm. “Here’s what I’m going to do,” she said. “You’re going to be attached to the hand bar at the top of the treadmill by this thread. It’s just long enough that you may, or may not be stepped on by me,” she tantalized. “If you can survive the half hour that I’m going to run on the treadmill, I’ll do nothing else to you today. No exceptions.”
I gulped as she tied the string to the treadmill, knowing that the chances of me surviving were very small. She stepped onto the track and turned the machine onto the first setting. Immediately, I began to move towards her feet as the treadmill came to life. I ran, trying to stay as far away from her as possible, but it was only walking speed and I was barely keeping up with her. I watched as she turned the knob, increasing the speed. I ran as fast as I could, but I was already beginning to lose distance. Then she rabidly turned the knob to a running speed. I had no chance to brace myself.
The ground flew out under me and I hit the sandpaper track on my stomach. It scraped my neck and face, rubbing the skin raw. I yelped at the pain and lifted up my head to keep it from hitting the track, but that wasn’t my biggest fear. The track had forced me straight towards Adrianna’s falling feet. If I got caught under one of them, I was surely a goner. They were landing on either side of me, just barely grazing my side. I screamed in terror as Adrianna began to move side to side, almost trying to step on me. I kicked with my legs, rolling to the sides to avoid her massive feet, all the while the treadmill scraping any exposed skin on my body and grating the flesh until it was bloody. It had become a game of cat and mouse; I could hear Adrianna laughing at my terror as I scrambled to avoid her deadly footfalls. I grabbed the string with my hands, trying desperately to climb my way away from the danger zone. With every ounce of strength I could muster, I pulled myself forward, millimeter by millimeter until I was a safer distance away, but it didn’t last. Adrianna brought her hand down onto the string, wrenching it from my hands and causing me to rush right back towards her feet. I was doomed. Sooner or later her feet would land true and crush me under it. There was no way I could survive 30 minutes of this. It had barely been five! I had to get out.
I wrestled with the string tied to my arms, trying to loosen it. Adrianna had tied it tight, but I was desperate enough to do anything to get out. The string cut into my wrists, drawing blood but I didn’t care. I could feel it loosening, starting to give way. I wrenched my wrists, ignoring the pain. Finally, one hand pulled free and the other hand followed suit. I hit the track and instead of it dragging across me like sandpaper, I shot right off of it, through Adrianna’s legs and landed safely on the carpet. I lay there, panting in relief. Then I heard the treadmill stop and Adrianna get off. She stood over me, bending down to look at me.
“You got lucky there, little Johnny,” she sneered. “I guess I didn’t expect you to escape the string. Oh, well. I’ll still remain true to my promise. You’re free from me for today, but not from my family.”
“What?!” I cried in disbelief.
“You found a loophole, why can’t I? Now I just have to decide who to lend you to…”
Oh, I was not going to like this at all.
~Torch~

121132211112122211121112.content:
<John>
She reached down and picked me up. I flinched as her fingers touched my raw and sensitive skin. I knew my situation had just gotten worse. If her family was as cruel as she was, well… I really didn’t want to think about the outcome. She carried me up the stairs and down the hallway. At first I thought Adrianna was going to enter her room, but she turned to the left and knocked on a closed door instead. The door opened and we were greeted by a tall woman, somewhere in her early twenties, with blond hair and purple and pink highlights. She had pierced eyebrows, lips, and nose and she had way too much makeup on. She was wearing a pair of jeans and a plain white tank top and she reeked of cigarette smoke. This had to be Adrianna’s older sister.
“Hi, Kelsey,” Adrianna said.
“What do you want?” her sister curtly replied. “I’m busy.”
“Oh, I’m sure, but I knew you wouldn’t want to miss out on what I have to show you.” Adrianna lifted me up until I was level with Kelsey’s face. My heart beat rapidly inside my chest out of fear. I just stared as recognition passed over Kelsey’s face and her lips curved into a wicked smile.
“That’s an ugly looking bug you have there,” she sneered and stepped out of the way to let Adrianna in. Her room was a mess. Clothes laid all over the floor and bed and garbage was piled up in one corner of the room. Her dresser was littered with various objects to the point of no open space. Her room was dark with the only light coming from the sunlight shining through the pale white curtains.
Kelsey walked over to a nightstand and pushed some things off of it and onto the floor to make room.
“Set him down there,” she ordered Adrianna. Adrianna obeyed, dropping me on the wooden surface. I hit it with a thud and quickly turned around to see Kelsey’s finger push down on my chest, holding me in place. She laughed once and then reached into her pocket and pulled out a cigarette.
“So how’d you get like this, little man?” she asked me.
“I…I don’t know.” I watched as she stuck the cigarette in her mouth and lit it with a lighter from her pocket. She breathed a cloud of smoke before speaking again.
“In any case it doesn’t really matter. I’ve never liked your family.”
“And why is that?”
She bent down and took a draught from her cigarette, blowing the smoke directly into my face. I coughed violently, shaking my head side to side to find clean air. She chuckled at my discomfort.
“Your family is a bunch of liars and thieves. You’re dad got rich by stealing ideas from other people and jipping money from the government. Nothing he did was for the benefit of others; he did it just to make himself look good and in turn get more money. And your mom was just a b**** who married your dad just for his money.”
“That’s not true!” I yelled. I was burning in anger, furious that she would say such things. She bent down again until she was an inch from my face.
“Oh, it’s true, and their son was the worst. He took advantage of people, using his money to gain popularity and then taking what he wanted from them and leaving them high and dry. He made himself out to be a saint, giving to charities and such, but it was all an act. He’s really just a stubborn, selfish, son of a b****, ba*****. And you know what I have to say to that?”
“What?” I said through clenched teeth.
“This.” She lifted up my shirt with one of her fingers and, before I could do anything about it, stuck the end of the cigarette directly into my stomach. The pain was like nothing I had ever felt before. I screamed as I could feel it burning into my skin, destroying flesh and nerves. I writhed around trying to avoid the pain but I couldn’t. Finally, after about five seconds, she lifted the end off of me and I laid there whimpering in agony. An ugly black circle had been burned into my skin directly above my bellybutton.
She took another inhale from her cigarette and breathed it into my face again. “Aww, did that hurt the little ba*****? I’m sorry; I won’t do that to your tummy again.” Another wicked grin passed over her face and I shuddered as I realized what she was going to do. With one flick of her finger, she rolled me onto my chest and pushed me down again, pulling my shirt up in the back. This time I thrashed violently to get away, but I stood no chance. Again the cigarette came down upon my skin, and again I screamed in horrible agony. Tears blinded my eyes and stung my cheeks as I fought against the anguish. She removed the cigarette again, but she was far from done. Pushing down on the rest of my body, she secured my arm and shoved the burning embers into my wrist. My vision went red as I screamed myself hoarse. I could hear her laughing at my torment and Adrianna joining in from beside her. Kelsey lifted the cigarette, but it continued to burn in all the places it had touched. She turned me over again and this time started taking off one of my shoes.
“Please! No more! Enough!” I begged as I squirmed and thrashed. Through my tear-blurred vision I watched Kelsey raise the cigarette, its end burning like the Devil’s pitchfork, and thrust it into the sole of my foot. The pain, the pain! It coursed through my body like it was all on fire! I had no more voice to shout, no more energy to withstand it. The last thing I heard was the laughing of those two demon sisters. Then everything went black.
~Torch~

1211322111121222111211121.content:
<John>
I woke up in pain. My chest, back, wrist, and foot felt like they were continually on fire. My whole body ached from being bruised and battered. I didn’t even try to move. Instead I opened my eyes and observed my surroundings. I was back in the cage, lying on my back. Adrianna was nowhere to be found. Slowly, I began to sit up, using my good arm to push myself into a sitting position. Just then, I felt the vibrations of footsteps through the cage floor and I looked up to see Adrianna approach the cage.
“Finally, you’re awake!” She exclaimed. “You’ve been out for two and a half days! It’s already nighttime!”
She bent down and began pushing objects through the top of the cage. I half expected to see more rodent pellets rain down around me, but instead she dropped a small chunk of bread beside me. I lunged for it immediately, ravenously shoving it into my mouth. It was dry and stale, but it was food.
“As much as I would like to let you starve, you won’t survive if you don’t have any strength,” she scowled. “So eat up and wrap up your wounds. I’m not touching them.”
Wrap up my wounds? I was just about to ask her what she meant when she pushed through the bars of the cage some gaze, strips of bandages, and an open tube of antiseptic. Then she stood up and lay on her bed out of my range of view. I stuffed the rest of the bread in my mouth and crawled over to the first aid supplies. I began tearing chunks of the gaze off and squirting small amounts of antiseptic onto them. Then I placed them on my wounds and wrapped the bandage strips around them. One by one, I wrapped my burn wounds and the areas of skin that had been rubbed raw by the treadmill. Everything that I could cover I did, and I felt very satisfied afterwards.
I lay down on my back and stared up at the top of the cage, surprised by this act of kindness that Adrianna had shown me, but then I realized that she just wanted to keep me alive so she could torture me some more. It was a kind but cruel gesture, but I was still thankful for it. My eyes grew heavy and I closed them, grateful that I was still alive.
~Torch~
